author: bridge-bot
content: <ivokub> Hi, I'm Ivo from Linea and just joined the group. Has there been any additional discussion/consensus on EIP-7667 (hash function gas repricing) after it was discussed last time in spring? I'd volunteer to collect benchmarks for proving costs on different zkEVMs and effect on transaction gas cost for some samples of transactions to figure out what should the gas multiplier be. (re @eliastzr: As soon as Stone and later Stwo is easily runnable in a docker on Kakarot I‚Äôd be happy to contribute to the open benchmark effort)

author: bridge-bot
content: <eliastzr> benchmarks would be welcome!! üôè (re @ivokub: Hi, I'm Ivo from Linea and just joined the group. Has there been any additional discussion/consensus on EIP-7667 (hash function gas repricing) after it was discussed last time in spring? I'd volunteer to collect benchmarks for proving costs on different zkEVMs and effect on transaction gas cost for some samples of transactions to figure out what should the gas multiplier be.)

author: bridge-bot
content: <eliastzr> my guess is that what you‚Äôll be benchmarking are the builtin/precompiles/accelerated chips for hashes by different zkevm(/zkvm) teams for non-zk friendly hashes

author: bridge-bot
content: <eliastzr> but this is a great idea üí° (re @ivokub: Hi, I'm Ivo from Linea and just joined the group. Has there been any additional discussion/consensus on EIP-7667 (hash function gas repricing) after it was discussed last time in spring? I'd volunteer to collect benchmarks for proving costs on different zkEVMs and effect on transaction gas cost for some samples of transactions to figure out what should the gas multiplier be.)

author: bridge-bot
content: <ivokub> Exactly - to see what is the runtime for proving hashes only compared to average transaction (per gas). And to figure out what is the overhead. There has been a lot of improvements recently. (re @eliastzr: my guess is that what you‚Äôll be benchmarking are the builtin/precompiles/accelerated chips for hashes by different zkevm(/zkvm) teams for non-zk friendly hashes)

author: bridge-bot
content: <eliastzr> would love to help for kakarot (re @ivokub: Exactly - to see what is the runtime for proving hashes only compared to average transaction (per gas). And to figure out what is the overhead. There has been a lot of improvements recently.)

author: bridge-bot
content: <drortirosh> /zkvm

author: bridge-bot
content:
<CarlBeek> Reminder RollCall #9 starts in 1 hour:

Agenda: https://github.com/ethereum/pm/issues/1172
Zoom: https://ethereumfoundation.zoom.us/j/82673576599?pwd=5eM5d0bqTKZvCeXIWEAmMc8Hk6zm2k.1

author: bridge-bot
content:
<adietrichs> I think a more abstract question here is the L2 EVM angle. Traditionally, with L2s following the L1 EVM changes, it would be a reasonable discussion to ask "should the L1 change its pricing in a way to make L2s that copy that spec change run more efficiently?", but a big part of my intentions behind embracing RIPs and the L2ECC is to give each layer the execution system that is optimally tailored to its needs.

So in that sense, I would much prefer having the conversation of "what would it take for just the zk rollups to ship this as an RIP?", with the idea that optimistic rollups and L1 would only ship it once zk proving performance becomes relevant there. (re @ivokub: Hi, I'm Ivo from Linea and just joined the group. Has there been any additional discussion/consensus on EIP-7667 (hash function gas repricing) after it was discussed last time in spring? I'd volunteer to collect benchmarks for proving costs on different zkEVMs and effect on transaction gas cost for some samples of transactions to figure out what should the gas multiplier be.)

author: bridge-bot
content:
<eliastzr> So step 1: make it a optional RIP, that ZK-EVMs will probably adopt
step 2: when ORUs switch to ZK they‚Äôll adopt it too
step 3: when L1 becomes Zk, this RIP will be converted to an EIP (re @adietrichs: I think a more abstract question here is the L2 EVM angle. Traditionally, with L2s following the L1 EVM changes, it would be a reasonable discussion to ask "should the L1 change its pricing in a way to make L2s that copy that spec change run more efficiently?", but a big part of my intentions behind embracing RIPs and the L2ECC is to give each layer the execution system that is optimally tailored to its needs.

So in that sense, I would much prefer having the conversation of "what would it take for just the zk rollups to ship this as an RIP?", with the idea that optimistic rollups and L1 would only ship it once zk proving performance becomes relevant there.)

author: bridge-bot
content: <adietrichs> yes, at least that would be the "rollcall philosophy" approach to that!

author: bridge-bot
content: <eliastzr> But time lapses between spaces might change the reality of this

author: bridge-bot
content: <eliastzr> since keccak was v expensive a year ago in ZK, now it‚Äôs less true

author: bridge-bot
content: <adietrichs> yes, good example

author: bridge-bot
content: <adietrichs> to flag this though - this is a general conversation we should be having as we are nearing the point where we have the tools that would enable L2s to more decisively fork off of the L1 execution spec (enabled by L2ECC and having all clients (in the geth case via rollup-geth) now embracing RIPs). E.g. my understanding is that @justindrake and @vb271828 have in the past argued for keeping L1 and L2 execution specs tightly coupled, to keep a path open to native rollups in the future (re @adietrichs: yes, at least that would be the "rollcall philosophy" approach to that!)

author: bridge-bot
content: <adietrichs> of course, we could get to a similar future via L2ECC - maybe if we ever ship enshrined rollup verification, there could be two targets available, L1 and L2 common core

author: bridge-bot
content: <adietrichs> (it's of course currently highly speculative whether L1 will ever go in that direction to begin with)

author: bridge-bot
content:
<ivokub> I guess it could be also interesting to see how it could work as a RIP - if it doesn't work out there is always an option to fallback to EIP process.

From Linea's point of view, we want to keep supporting multiple clients and in this case adapting RIPs would require maintaining several forks (for now geth, Besu, Erigon and Nethermind). And in that context, I am not too sure it would be sustainable.

author: bridge-bot
content: <CarlBeek> EIPs are always an option and if you have reason to think that some feature is important for mainnet and is likely to ship on L1, then you should start with an EIP.

author: bridge-bot
content:
<adietrichs> bumping call link for the call now, see you all on there üôÇ (re @CarlBeek: Reminder RollCall #9 starts in 1 hour:

Agenda: https://github.com/ethereum/pm/issues/1172
Zoom: https://ethereumfoundation.zoom.us/j/82673576599?pwd=5eM5d0bqTKZvCeXIWEAmMc8Hk6zm2k.1)

author: bridge-bot
content:
<CarlBeek> RollCall #9 starts now

Agenda: https://github.com/ethereum/pm/issues/1172
Zoom: https://ethereumfoundation.zoom.us/j/82673576599?pwd=5eM5d0bqTKZvCeXIWEAmMc8Hk6zm2k.1

author: bridge-bot
content:
<adietrichs> As discussed on the call just now, two next steps for the L2 Execution Common Core (formerly L2 EVM Common Core):

- we have a working group for exploring the possible scope for a L2ECC v1: https://t.me/+gadsOqat4K01ZDhi

- we'll have a second L2ECC brekout call on January 22: https://github.com/ethereum/pm/issues/1215

author: bridge-bot
content: <adietrichs> no worries if you don't have the bandwidth for joining the working group, the intention is just to keep the conversation going so that we have progress to talk about on that next breakout call. there won't be any decisions made within the working group before then.

author: bridge-bot
content:
<stanbreadless> Just in case to follow up: the feeHistory changes / EIP7762 don‚Äôt affect zkSync

Also, about the 32-byte chain id, I was referring to this ERC: https://github.com/ethereum/ERCs/pull/735 <@543900561460822016>
